docs.text: Introduction These pages describe the RADx Metadata Specification . This metadata specification contains a meta template that specifies required, recommended and optional fields that are used for capturing metadata that described data files submitted to the RADx Data Hub . We recommend that you start by reading the specification . After this, you can learn about the different ways of creating metadata instances that describe individual data files and comply with the specification that is described here.
docs.title: Home

docs.title: Introduction

docs.text: About Development of the Metadata Specification The RADx Metadata Specification adopts a widely used community standard (DataCite 3.4) for describing data files. After defining (in a Google sheet) the important DataCite attributes to include in the specification, these attributes were encoded as a JSON-LD specification using the CEDAR Workbench . The JSON-LD specification is the document we call the RADx Metadata Specification. It uses a schema format called the CEDAR Template Model, which is designed so that individual metadata descriptions (the metadata files provided by the RADx (C)DCCs to the Data Hub) contain well-defined values. With this approach, the RADx metadata will conform to a well-described JSON-LD syntax and can be validated easily at any time. For this release of the RADx Metadata Specification, we adopted much of the DataCite specification, following a pattern previously set by another community that created a Generic Dataset Metadata Template in CEDAR. We then added several sections of metadata that allowed more detailed provenance descriptions of the data, and adjusted many of the field descriptions so RADx users could better understand what was expected. Finally, we wrote software to convert our Google Sheet metadata specification into a CEDAR Template in the CEDAR Template Model format, and verified its operation by filling out working metadata examples. The verified template is submitted to the Metadata Specification Repository in GitHub.

docs.text: This page describes the basic operations we expect providers of RADx metadata will perform. In some cases the RADx Data Hub support team may be able to help you perform these operations, please contact us at the RADx Support contact address. While many of the artifacts (or examples of them) mentioned in this section can be found in the RADx metadata-specification GitHub repository, their primary location for easy viewing is in the CEDAR repository. You can find the latest links in the README file of the GitHub repository. Detailed explanations of CEDAR operations described in this manual are described in the CEDAR User's Guide. RADx Metadata Specification Template The RADx Metadata Specification Template specifies the metadata format to describe data files or other digital objects submitted to the RADx Data Hub. You can create metadata that conforms to this specification in several ways, as described in the next section. Because the RADx Metadata Specification Template is a JSON Schema, it can be used to validate the Metadata Instances described in the next section. There are online tools as well as software libraries that can be used to perform this validation. The validation only addresses the syntactic organization of the Metadata Instance, it does not check to see if the contents of metadata fields are meaningful. RADx Metadata Instances: Creating Metadata Descriptions We use the term Metadata Instance to refer to a JSON-LD file that conforms to the RADx Metadata Specification template. There are several ways you may want to create a Metadata Instance. Creating a Metadata Instance by Hand (CEDAR) The simplest way to create a valid metadata Instance is to find the Metadata Specification Template, click on the metadata tag or the drop-down menu item 'Populate', and fill out the resulting form and save it. You can view the result while the Metadata Editor is open by using the JSON-LD button at the bottom of the screen, and copy and paste the revealed text document to a text file for viewing. Creating a Reusable Metadata Instance (CEDAR) In another scenario, you may want to partially fill out a Metadata Instance with information that will be the same in many other Metadata Instances. Then that Instance can be used as a 'prefilled with defaults' document from which others can create their own documents. To do this, manually create the Metadata Instance that will contain the shared 'default' data. To let others copy it, make it read-only accessible to their accounts using the drop-down 'Share' menu. (You can specify the name of their account, or you can give the group 'Everybody' read permission.) If you give them the name of the document, they can search for it, and use the drop-down menu in the file viewer dashboard to make a copy of it in their own directory. They can edit their copy (which will include the values you have already set) to produce a new Metadata Instance. Automatically Generating a Metadata Instance (external) The rigorous way to create a CEDAR Metadata Instance is to understand the content in the CEDAR Template, Element, and Field Instances guidance. This is an important reference but there is a significant shortcut available. The easiest way to generate Metadata Instances computationally is to start by creating an example Metadata Instance that has all the metadata fields filled out that you care about. Use recognizable dummy values (e.g., 'zzzz' for text, '9999' for numbers) that you can search for later. Save your Metadata Instance and transfer the saved text into a text editor. Now you can search for all your dummy entries, to see the exact section of the document you need to replace with your own values. You could imagine a gigantic print statement in your source code to print the document all at once, or separate print statements for each variable of interest. While the order of items at the same level does not matter, the JSON nesting must be preserved. You have a choice when it comes to filling out the @id for the document (usually near the top) and the metadata parameters about the document (when it was created or update, by whom, etc.). You either have to set those to 'null', as suggested here, and leave them unfilled; or alternatively, you can use the CEDAR REST API to submit your Metadata Instance and turn it into a fully described CEDAR Metadata Instance document. (The API returns the identifier of the Instance, which you can use to retrieve it.) Eventually we may make this last step an automated part of the RADx ingest pipeline; in the meantime, performing some submissions of your content to CEDAR can help you verify that you are correctly completing a well-formed Metadata Instance. It is also possible to validate a Metadata Instance against the Metadata Specification Template, as described earlier. We recommend you make this a part of your Metadata Instance generation pipeline.
docs.title: Creating Metadata

docs.text: code { max-height: 15em; overflow-y: scroll; } Preliminaries The metadata template that is described in these pages is normatively specified using a CEDAR Template. This page describes the terminology that we use when talking about a template. Terminology Instances A metadata instance is a document that specifies some specific metadata for some specific data. For example, given a data file, the metadata for the file may describe the file creation date and the name of the person that created the file. Metadata instances are represented using JSON documents, or more specifically JSON-LD (JSON for Linked Data) documents. A portion of a metadata instances that describes the creation of a file is shown below. You should not worry about understanding the formatting or meaning of this snippet at this stage. This metadata specifies that the file was created on October 10, 2022 at 16:44:03 (4:44pm) GMT, it specifies the identifer for the person who created the file as https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1825-0097 and the name of the person who created the file as "Josiah Carberry". In this case, the identifier for the person is an ORCID . "Creation Date" { "@value" : "2022-10-10T16:44:03.195Z" }, "Creator Identifier" { "@id" : "https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1825-0097" }, "Creator Name": { "@value": "Josiah Carberry" } Templates A metadata template is a schema for metadata instances. Following on from the example above, a metadata template would specify that the "Creation Date" is a date/time, that the "Creator Identifier" field is a string that represents an Internationalized Resource Identifier (IRI), and that the "Creator Name" field is a string. At their core metadata templates are specified as JSON-Schema. They do however also contain other details, for example information that can be used to generate user-interfaces for metadata instance collection. Like metadata instances, templates contain JSON Linked Data (JSON-LD) markup that is used to embed semantic information into the template that precisely specifies the meaning of "Creation Date", "Creator Identifier" and "Creator Name". This JSON-LD markup is most visible as @context objects that are spread throughout a template. An example of the template description of the "Creator Identifier" field that was used in the metadata instance description is shown below. As can be seen, the JSON-Schema/JSON-LD representation of metadata templates is quite verbose and considerably more complex and intimidating that the simple representation of metadata instances. We only provide this example here so you can seen what a fragment of a template looks like. "Creator Identifier": { "@type": "https://schema.metadatacenter.org/core/TemplateField", "@id": "https://repo.metadatacenter.org/template-fields/f88856cc-5b85-444a-bbd1-7d56ff71ed34", "schema:identifier": "creator_identifier", "schema:name": "Creator Identifier", "schema:description": "Globally unique string that identifies the creator (an individual or legal entity).", "pav:derivedFrom": "", "skos:prefLabel": "Creator Identifier", "skos:altLabel": [], "pav:version": "0.9.1", "bibo:status": "bibo:draft", "_valueConstraints": { "defaultValue": "", "requiredValue": false, "multipleChoice": false }, "_ui": { "inputType": "textfield" }, "pav:createdOn": null, "pav:createdBy": null, "pav:lastUpdatedOn": null, "oslc:modifiedBy": null, "type": "object", "title": "Field(Creator Identifier)", "description": "Generated by CSV2CEDAR.", "properties": { "@type": { "oneOf": [ { "type": "string", "format": "uri" }, { "type": "array", "minItems": 1, "items": { "type": "string", "format": "uri" }, "uniqueItems": true } ] }, "@value": { "type": [ "string", "null" ] }, "rdfs:label": { "type": [ "string", "null" ] } }, "additionalProperties": false, "schema:schemaVersion": "1.6.0", "@context": { "xsd": "http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#", "pav": "http://purl.org/pav/", "bibo": "http://purl.org/ontology/bibo/", "oslc": "http://open-services.net/ns/core#", "schema": "http://schema.org/", "skos": "http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#", "schema:name": { "@type": "xsd:string" }, "schema:description": { "@type": "xsd:string" }, "skos:prefLabel": { "@type": "xsd:string" }, "skos:altLabel": { "@type": "xsd:string" }, "pav:createdOn": { "@type": "xsd:dateTime" }, "pav:createdBy": { "@type": "@id" }, "pav:lastUpdatedOn": { "@type": "xsd:dateTime" }, "oslc:modifiedBy": { "@type": "@id" } }, "$schema": "http://json-schema.org/draft-04/schema#" } Fields A field is the most basic descriptive unit of a metadata template. The key aspects of a field are that is has a name (for example "Creator Identifier"), a description (or help text). Fields are either directly or indirectly embedded into template to form a complate metadata description. Elements An element is an ordered collection of fields and other nested elements. For example, we may have a "Creator" element that comprises the "Creator Identifier", "First Name" and "Last Name" fields. Like fields, elements have a name and a description, amongst other attributes. The artifacts contained in an element may have multiplicities assigned to them. Thus, we can say that a field in an element is required (min 1) and/or single valued (max 1). Technologies Template, fields and elements make heavy use of JSON-Schema and JSON for Linking Data (JSON-LD) . We provide a very brief summary of these technlogies here. For more detailed information on these technologies please see the linked Web sites. JSON-Schema Like XML Schema for XML documents, JSON-Schema provides a declarative way of describing JSON documents and a JSON-Schema can be used to validate a JSON document. JSON-LD JSON-LD adds Semantic markup to JSON, making the meaning of JSON documents precise and increasing interoperability across the Web. Indeed, search engines such as Google take advantage of JSON-LD markup to discover the unambiguous meaning of information in JSON documents. For our purposes, JSON-LD aids us in making metadata FAIR – F indable, A ccessible, I nteroperable and R esuable.
docs.title: Preliminaries

As can be seen, the JSON-Schema/JSON-LD representation of metadata templates is quite verbose and considerably more complex and intimidating that the simple representation of metadata instances. We only provide this example here so you can seen what a fragment of a template looks like. "Creator Identifier": { "@type": "https://schema.metadatacenter.org/core/TemplateField", "@id": "https://repo.metadatacenter.org/template-fields/f88856cc-5b85-444a-bbd1-7d56ff71ed34", "schema:identifier": "creator_identifier", "schema:name": "Creator Identifier", "schema:description": "Globally unique string that identifies the creator (an individual or legal entity).", "pav:derivedFrom": "", "skos:prefLabel": "Creator Identifier", "skos:altLabel": [], "pav:version": "0.9.1", "bibo:status": "bibo:draft", "_valueConstraints": { "defaultValue": "", "requiredValue": false, "multipleChoice": false }, "_ui": { "inputType": "textfield" }, "pav:createdOn": null, "pav:createdBy": null, "pav:lastUpdatedOn": null, "oslc:modifiedBy": null, "type": "object", "title": "Field(Creator Identifier)", "description": "Generated by CSV2CEDAR.", "properties": { "@type": { "oneOf": [ { "type": "string", "format": "uri" }, { "type": "array", "minItems": 1, "items": { "type": "string", "format": "uri" }, "uniqueItems": true } ] }, "@value": { "type": [ "string", "null" ] }, "rdfs:label": { "type": [ "string", "null" ] } }, "additionalProperties": false, "schema:schemaVersion": "1.6.0", "@context": { "xsd": "http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#", "pav": "http://purl.org/pav/", "bibo": "http://purl.org/ontology/bibo/", "oslc": "http://open-services.net/ns/core#", "schema": "http://schema.org/", "skos": "http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#", "schema:name": { "@type": "xsd:string" }, "schema:description": { "@type": "xsd:string" }, "skos:prefLabel": { "@type": "xsd:string" }, "skos:altLabel": { "@type": "xsd:string" }, "pav:createdOn": { "@type": "xsd:dateTime" }, "pav:createdBy": { "@type": "@id" }, "pav:lastUpdatedOn": { "@type": "xsd:dateTime" }, "oslc:modifiedBy": { "@type": "@id" } }, "$schema": "http://json-schema.org/draft-04/schema#" }
docs.title: Templates

docs.text: A field is the most basic descriptive unit of a metadata template. The key aspects of a field are that is has a name (for example "Creator Identifier"), a description (or help text). Fields are either directly or indirectly embedded into template to form a complate metadata description.
docs.title: Fields

docs.text: An element is an ordered collection of fields and other nested elements. For example, we may have a "Creator" element that comprises the "Creator Identifier", "First Name" and "Last Name" fields. Like fields, elements have a name and a description, amongst other attributes. The artifacts contained in an element may have multiplicities assigned to them. Thus, we can say that a field in an element is required (min 1) and/or single valued (max 1).
docs.title: Elements

docs.text: Template, fields and elements make heavy use of JSON-Schema and JSON for Linking Data (JSON-LD) . We provide a very brief summary of these technlogies here. For more detailed information on these technologies please see the linked Web sites.
docs.title: Technologies

docs.text: Like XML Schema for XML documents, JSON-Schema provides a declarative way of describing JSON documents and a JSON-Schema can be used to validate a JSON document.
docs.title: JSON-Schema

docs.text: JSON-LD adds Semantic markup to JSON, making the meaning of JSON documents precise and increasing interoperability across the Web. Indeed, search engines such as Google take advantage of JSON-LD markup to discover the unambiguous meaning of information in JSON documents. For our purposes, JSON-LD aids us in making metadata FAIR – F indable, A ccessible, I nteroperable and R esuable.
docs.title: JSON-LD

docs.text: Resources These pages describe the RADx Metadata Specification in prose. The normative specification however is specified as a CEDAR template that can be viewed in the CEDAR Workbench. Please note that you will be required to log into the CEDAR Workbench to view this template. The CEDAR Workbench is a free Open-Source Web Application for creating, maintaining and populating semantic metadata templates. For more information please see the CEDAR Website .

docs.text: Specification Required fields The following fields are required fields. These fields MUST be filled out in a metadata instance for the instance to be valid. Data File Title >> Title Data File Parent Study >> PHS Identifier Recommended fields The following fields are recommended fields. These fields SHOULD be filled out in a metadata instance to greatly increase the likelihood of the associated data file being found by interested parties and to provide proper accreditation for the creators of the file. Data File Identity >> Identifier Data File Identity >> File Name Data File Content >> Type Of Content Data File Version >> Version Data File Subjects >> Subject Identifier Data File Description >> Description Data File Creator >> Creator Type Data File Creator >> Creator Name Data File Creator >> Creator Given Name Data File Creator >> Creator Family Name Data File Creator >> Creator Identifier Data File Creator >> Creator Email Data File Creator >> Creator Affiliation Data File Creator >> Creator Role Data File Parent Study >> Study Identifier Data File Parent Study >> Study Name Data File Funding Source >> Award Local Identifier Data File Funding Source >> Funder Name Data File Funding Source >> Funder Identifier Data File Title Multi-valued The name or title of the Data File being described. Mutliple titles may be specified in different languages. At least one Data File Title element is required. Title Required A title or descriptive name by which the Data File being described is known. This is a presentation name (i.e. title case with appropriate spacing) and is typically different from the actual file name of the data file. Example COVID-19 Booster Shot Side Effects Survey Responses Language Optional The language tag that identifies the language in which the Data File Title is provided. Languages are identified using codes that are structured in accordance with RFC 5646 . If no value is specified then the default code of en for English is assumed. A comprehensive list of language codes is provided here. If you cannot find an appropriate language code please contact the Data Hub administrators. The value of this field is a language code. See the language code table for a list of possible language codes. Example en Data File Identity Information about the globally unique and persistent identifier used to identify and optionally access (meta)data of the data file being described. Identifier Recommended A globally unique string that identifies the Data File being described. It is typically a DOI (Digital Object Identifier) or URL (Uniform Resource Locator, that is, Web address). The identifier is typically generated by data providers or data publishers who wish to have a citable and Web-accessible resource. Example DOIs are doi:10.1000/182 or http://doi.org/10.1000/182 , both of which identify the DOI Handbook, which has a DOI of 10.1000/182 See also: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_object_identifier Example doi:10.1000/182 Identifier Type Optional The identifier type used to identify the resource being described. This need not be provided if the identifier is either a DOI that begins with "doi:" or "http://doi.org/", or it is a URL that begins with either "http://" or "https://" Example DOI File Name Recommended The local name of the resource (for example, in a file-based operating system or web service). Example COVID-19_Booster_Shot_June_2022_Responses.csv SHA256 digest Optional A SHA256 digest of the Data File contents. This is a 64 characters long hexadecimal string. As an example, the SHA256 digest of the string, "RADx Data Hub" is ebff8d3da88b292622d3bfc36bdac4c4537ddc56cb07f344c5223d6b6f9cd011 . On macOS the following command may be used to generate the SHA256 digest of a file shasum -a 256 /path/to/file Example ebff8d3da88b292622d3bfc36bdac4c4537ddc56cb07f344c5223d6b6f9cd011 Data File Content Type Of Content Recommended The kind of content that the data file contains. Data files are either text or non-text (binary) representations of datasets, images etc. This field describes the conceptual type of the thing that is represented by the data file. In most cases the value of this field will "Data Set" but other common types include "Audiovisual", "Data Stream", "Image"" Audiovisual | Collection | Data Catalog | Data Paper | Data Stream | Dataset | Event | Image | Interactive Resource | Model | Other Resource | Physical Object | Service | Software | Sound | Text | Workflow Example Data Set Type of Content Description Optional If no suitable value can be specified for the Type Of Content field then this field may contain a brief free-text description of the conceptual type of content Data File Version Version of the resource being described. Version Recommended The string identifying the version of the data file or other resource being described. We recommend that provides use semantic versioning of the form, major.minor.patch for example, 2.1.4 . Example 1.0.1 Data File Language Language in which the data file being described is provided. Primary Language Optional Primary language used to present the data file (if multiple languages are present). The value of this field is a language code. See the language code table for a list of possible language codes. Example en Other Language Optional Multi-valued A language in which the data file being described is provided. The value of this field is a language code. See the language code table for a list of possible language codes. Data File Subjects Multi-valued Concepts (keywords, classification, or free text terms) that define the data file or purpose (subjects which can be addressed) using the data file. Subject Identifier Recommended The Medical Subject Headings (MeSH) subject code that identifies a classification subject that is pertinent to the data file. Example http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/MESH/C000719227 Subject Identifier Scheme Derived Optional This value is derived This field should not be manually specified or edited. The name of the scheme or authority used for the Subject Identifier. Subject Identifier Scheme Identifier Derived Optional This value is derived This field should not be manually specified or edited. The unique identifier (IRI) of the scheme or authority used for the Subject Identifier. Keyword Optional Free text subject, keyword, classification code, or key phrase describing the data file or purpose for which the data file can be used. While MeSH codes are the preferred form of specifying subjects this free text field may be used for codes or subject keywords that do not have a corresponding MeSH terms. Example COVID-19 vaccine booster shot Data File Description Multi-valued Summary of the Data File and its contents. Description Recommended An account of the resource contained in the Data File; may include but is not limited to: an abstract, a table of contents, a graphical representation, or a free-text account of the resource. Example This dataset provides responses from a survey carried out in June 2022 whose purpose was to ascertain side-effects of receiving the COVID-19 booster shot. Description Language Optional Language in which the Data File description is provided. The default value is en for English. The value of this field is a language code. See the language code table for a list of possible language codes. Example en Data File Dictionary Information about the Data Dictionary associated with the Data File Data Dictionary File Name Optional The file name of the Data Dictionary file that defines the Data File's data elements. Example COVID-19_Booster_Shot_June_2022_Responses--DataDictionary.csv Data File Creator Multi-valued Information about the person or organization that created the data file. Creator Type Recommended The type of the creator. This is either a Person or an Organization. Organization | Person Example Person Creator Name Recommended The full name of the creator. For a person this is the combination of the given name and family name, in the appropriate order. Example Josiah Carberry Creator Given Name Recommended If the creator is a person, the personal name(s) of the creator (e.g., first and optionally middle name in Western languagues, optionally middle and last name in Asian languages). Example Josiah Creator Family Name Recommended If the creator is a person, the surname(s) of the creator (e.g., last name in Western languagues, first name in Asian languages). Example Carberry Creator Identifier Recommended Globally unique string that identifies the creator (an individual or legal entity). This is typically an ORCID. The ORCID iD is an https URI with a 16-digit number that is compatible with the ISO Standard (ISO 27729), also known as the International Standard Name Identifier (ISNI), e.g. https://orcid.org/0000-0001-2345-6789 ORCID provides a persistent digital identifier (an ORCID iD) that you own and control, and that distinguishes you from every other researcher. You can connect your iD with your professional information — affiliations, grants, publications, peer review, and more. You can use your iD to share your information with other systems, ensuring you get recognition for all your contributions, saving you time and hassle, and reducing the risk of errors. For more details on ORCiDs see https://orgid.org Example https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1825-0097 Creator Identifier Scheme Optional The name of the scheme or authority used for the Creator Identifier. If the Creator Identiifier is an ORCID that starts with https://orcid.org then there is no need to fill out this field. GRID | ISNI | LinkedIn ID | ORCiD | ResearcherID | ROR | Scopus Example ORCID Creator Identifier Scheme Identifier Derived Optional The value of this field is derived from the value of the Creator Identifier Scheme field. This field should not be manually specified or edited. The unique identifier (IRI) of the scheme or authority used for the Creator Identifier. If the Creator Identiifier is an ORCID that starts with https://orcid.org then there is no need to fill out this field. Creator Email Recommended The email address of the creator. Example josiah.carberry@example.com Creator Affiliation Recommended If the creator is a Person who is affiliated with an instition then this field should specify the institution. Example Brown University Creator Affiliation Identifier Optional Globally unique string that identifies the organizational affiliation of the creator. Example https://ror.org/05gq02987 Creator Affiliation Identifier Scheme Optional The name of the scheme or authority used for the Creator Affiliation Identifier. GRID | ISNI | LinkedIn ID | ORCiD | ResearcherID | ROR | Scopus Example ROR Creator Affiliation Identifier Scheme Identifier Derived Optional The value of this field is derived from the Creator Affiliation Scheme field This field should not be manually specified or edited. The unique identifier (IRI) of the scheme or authority used for the Subject Identifier. Creator Role Recommended The role of the Person or the Organization in relation to the data file creation. Contact Person | Data Collector | Data Curator | Data Manager | Distributor | Editor | Hosting Institution | Other Role | Producer | Project Leader | Project Manager | Project Member | Registration Agency | Registration Authority | Related Person | Research Group | Researcher | Rights Holder | Sponsor | Supervisor | Work Package Leader Data File Related Resource Multi-valued Information about resource related to the data file or other entity being described. TODO: INSERT MORE EXPLANATION HERE Related Resource Identifier Optional A globally unique string that identifies a resource that is related to the data file being described. Related Resource Identifier Type Optional The identifier type used to identify the related resource. ARK | arXiv | bibcode | DOI | EAN13 | EISSN | Handle | IGSN | IRI | ISBN | ISSN | ISTC | LISSN | LSID | PMID | PURL | UPC | URI | URL | URN | w3id Related Resource File Name Optional The local name of the related resource file (given by the operating system or web service). Resource Type Category Optional Categorical type of the resource being described. (Corresponds to DataCite's resourceTypeGeneral.) Audiovisual | Collection | Data Catalog | Data Paper | Data Stream | Dataset | Event | Image | Interactive Resource | Model | Other Resource | Physical Object | Service | Software | Sound | Text | Workflow Relation of Data File to Resource Optional Description of the relationship of the object being described (A) to the related resource (B). Data File Contributor Multi-valued An entity that contributed in bringing into existence the data file being described. Contributors can be people or organizations. While data file creators are also contributors, data file creators should be provided in the Data File Creator section instead of here Contributor Type Optional The type of the contributor of the described data file (person or organization). Organization | Person Example Person Contributor Name Optional The full name of the contributor. Example Josiah Carberry Contributor Given Name Optional If the contributor is a person, the personal name(s) of the contributor (e.g., first and optionally middle name in Western languagues, optionally middle and last name in Asian languages). Example Josiah Contributor Family Name Optional If the contributor is a person, the surname(s) of the conributor (e.g., last name in Western languagues, first name in Asian languages). Example Carberry Contributor Identifier Optional Globally unique string that identifies the contributor (an individual or legal entity). Example https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1825-0097 Contributor Identifier Scheme Optional The name of the scheme or authority used for the Contributor Identifier. GRID | ISNI | LinkedIn ID | ORCiD | ResearcherID | ROR | Scopus Example ORCID Contributor Identifier Scheme IRI Derived Optional The value of this field is derived from the value of the Contributor Identifier Scheme Field This field should not be manually specified or edited. The unique identifier (IRI) of the scheme or authority used for the Contributor Identifier. Contributor Affiliation Optional If the contributor is a person, the organizational or institutional affiliation of the contributor. Example Brown University Contributor Affiliation Identifier Optional Globally unique string that identifies the organizational affiliation of the contributor. Example https://ror.org/05gq02987 Contributor Affiliation Identifier Scheme Optional The name of the scheme or authority used for the Contributor Affiliation Identifier. GRID | ISNI | LinkedIn ID | ORCiD | ResearcherID | ROR | Scopus Example ROR Contributor Affiliation Identifier Scheme IRI Derived Optional The value of this field is derived from the value of the Contributor Affiliation Scheme Field This field should not be manually specified or edited. The unique identifier (IRI) of the scheme or authority used for the Contributor Affiliation Identifier Scheme. Contributor Email Optional An email address of the contributor. Example josiah.carberry@example.com Contributor Role Optional The role of the contributor in bringing the described data file into existence. Example Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International (CC BY-SA 4.0) Data File Date Multi-valued Relevant date related to the data file being described. These dates pertain to some data file related event, for example "creation date", "submission date" etc. Dates are specified as a pair containing the actual date (in ISO-8601 format) and the event that the date relates to. See individual fields for specific examples. The dates of some types of events can be captured by the RADx Data Hub, for example the "Submitted" date/time. Event Type Optional Type of data file event that the date is associated with. Accepted | Available | Collected | Copyrighted | Created | Issued | Published | Submitted | Updated | Valid | Withdrawn Example Submitted Date Optional The date/time that is specific to the associated event. Note that dates must be specified in ISO-8601 format. This format specifies date/times in a locale neutral way with temporal components ordered largest to smallest, for example year, month, day. Note that times are in 24 hour clock (military time) format, thus 13:43 is 1:43pm. When times are specified a timezone must also be specified. The date time 2022-11-23T01:23:45.678+09:00 specifies November 23, 2022 at just past 1:23am Pacific Time. The date 2022-09-23 specifies September 23, 2022 (without a time stamp). Example 2022-11-23T01:23:45.678+09:00 Data File Parent Study Multi-valued The research study for which this data file was created. PHS Identifier Required The PHS number, that identifies the study for which this data file was created. Example phs002691 Study Identifier Recommended Globally unique string that identifies the study for which this data file was created. Study Identifier Scheme Optional The name of the scheme or authority used for the Study Identifier. ARK | arXiv | bibcode | DOI | EAN13 | EISSN | Handle | IGSN | IRI | ISBN | ISSN | ISTC | LISSN | LSID | PMID | PURL | UPC | URI | URL | URN | w3id Study Identifier Scheme IRI Derived Optional The value of this field is automatically determined from the PHS Identifier field. This field should not be manually specified or edited. The unique identifier (IRI) of the scheme or authority used for the Study Identifier. Study Name Derived Recommended The value of this field is automatically determined from the PHS Identifier field. This field should not be manually specified or edited. The name of the research study for which this data file was created. Study Start Date Derived Optional The value of this field is automatically determined from the PHS Identifier field. This field should not be manually specified or edited. The official start date for the study for which this data file was created. This date must be in the ISO-8601 format of yyyy-mm-dd. For example, 2022-10-05 specified October 5, 2022. Example 2021-10-05 Study End Date Derived Optional The value of this field is automatically determined from the PHS Identifier field. This field should not be manually specified or edited. The official end date for the study for which this data file was created. This date must be in the ISO-8601 format of yyyy-mm-dd. For example, 2022-10-05 specified October 5, 2022. Example 2021-10-05 Data File Funding Source Multi-valued The sources of funding that enabled and drove the creation of the data file. (Non-monetary sources are described under Contributor.) Award Title Optional The human readable title of the award, grant, or other specific funding mechanism for the described data file. Award Page URL Optional The unique identifier (IRI) leading to a page provided by the funder for more information about the award (grant). Award Local Identifier Recommended The code assigned by the funding provider to a sponsored award (grant). (Can be an IRI, but typically is not.) Funder Name Recommended Name of the organization providing the funding for the described data file ('funding provider'). This is typically the NIH Institute that awarded the grant. Funder Identifier Recommended Globally unique string that identifies the funding provider. A list of NIH Institute identifiers may be found here . Optional Total size of data file distribution (in bytes). Distribution Access Protocol Optional The protocol used to access the data file distribution. Distribution Access Configuration Optional The access protocol configuration for querying the data file distribution. Distribution Query Statement Optional Technical statement(s) for querying the data file distribution. Data File Publication Date Publication date of this distribution the data file. Data File Publication Date Optional Date on which this distribution of the data file was published Publication Date Type Derived Optional The value of this field is a fixed type and is automatically inserted. This field should not be manually specified or edited. Type of the date ('Published') with respect to the data file. Data Characteristics Summary Characteristics of the data within the data file, particularly of the cohorts in the data file. Data Characteristics Table in HTML Optional Formatted HTML code for a table of statistical values Data Characteristics Table in CSV Optional Enter comma-separated values containing summary statistics characterizing this data file Data Characteristics Table in TSV Optional Enter tab-separated values containing summary statistics characterizing this data file Data Characteristics Table in Key-Value Pairs Optional Multi-valued Enter the name of the characteristic being described in the first (key) field, and the value for that characteristic in the second (value) field.. Note this is a repeating field and so can support multiple key-value pairs. Data Source Multi-valued Physical or conceptual entity (agent) that creates the data streams that make up the described data file. The data source may or may not be associated with a fixed location; for example, a series of discrete sensors deployed over time to a single location may be considered a single data source in some systems. Data Source Name Optional Human readable name of data source from which the variable(s) come(s). Physical or conceptual entity that creates the data streams that make up the described data file. The data source may or may not be associated with a fixed location; for example, a series of discrete sensors deployed over time to a single location may be considered a single data source in some systems. Data Source Identifier Optional Globally unique string that identifies the data source (e.g., PID of an instrument). Data Source Identifier Scheme Optional The name of the scheme or authority used for the Data Source Identifier. ARK | arXiv | bibcode | DOI | EAN13 | EISSN | Handle | IGSN | IRI | ISBN | ISSN | ISTC | LISSN | LSID | PMID | PURL | UPC | URI | URL | URN | w3id Data Source Identifier Scheme IRI Derived Optional The value of this field is derived from the Data Source Identifier Scheme field. This field should not be manually specified or edited. The unique identifier (IRI) of the scheme or authority used for the Data Source Identifier. Data Stream Multi-valued A collection of one or more variable records that make up this data set. Each data stream originates from a single data source (e.g., sensor, process, or person). A data stream can grow over time. Data Stream Name Optional Human readable name of collection of records coming from a data source. A data stream is a collection of one or more variable records originating from a single data source (e.g., sensor, process, or person). A data stream can grow over time. Data Stream Identifier Optional Globally unique string that identifies the collection of records coming from a data source. Data Stream Identifier Scheme Optional The name of the scheme or authority used for the Data Stream Identifier. ARK | arXiv | bibcode | DOI | EAN13 | EISSN | Handle | IGSN | IRI | ISBN | ISSN | ISTC | LISSN | LSID | PMID | PURL | UPC | URI | URL | URN | w3id Data Stream Identifier Scheme IRI Derived Optional The value of this field is derived from the Data Stream Identifier Scheme field. This field should not be manually specified or edited. The unique identifier (IRI) of the scheme or authority used for the Data Stream Identifier. Data Stream Variable Name Optional Multi-valued The local name of a variable contained in the data stream. Data Stream Data Source Identifier Optional Globally unique string that identifies the data source (e.g., PID of an instrument) that generated this Data Stream. Data File Creation Process Multi-valued Process (activity) used to make the data file or product. Process Name Optional Full name of the process that operates to make the data file or product. Process IRI Optional Unique identifier (IRI) for the process used to make the data file or product (preferably a resolvable and persistent identifier) Process Version Optional Version of the process used to make this data file, typically a string (e.g., '3.0.3') Process Execution Identifier Optional Identification of the particular run of the process used to make this data file (a deterministic string; in software, typically either a timestamp combined with the machine on which the software was executed; or a unique identifier generated by the controlling software for each run of the process). Data File Temporal Coverage Multi-valued A temporal description that specifies the temporal coverage of the data contained within the data file associated with this metadata. Temporal Extent Minimum Value Optional The start date (and optionally time) of the data. Example 2022-06-01 Temporal Extent Maximum Value Optional The end date (and optionally time) of the data. Example 2022-06-29 Temporal Resolution Optional Interval between two consecutive data records. Duration Derived Optional The value of this field is computed from the difference between the Temporal Extent Minimum Value and Temporal Extent Maximum Value fields. This field should not be manually specified or edited. The total duration of data temporal coverage. Data File Spatial Coverage Multi-valued A geospatial description that specifies the geographical coverage of the data contained within the data file associated with this metadata. Bounding Box Multi-valued A geographical bounding box that specifies the geographical coverage of the data contained within the data file associated with this metadata. Maximum Latitude Optional Location of the maximum, or northernmost, data point in this data file, expressed in decimal degrees (southern latitudes are negative). 37.5 specifies 37.5 degress North (37 degrees and 30 minutes North) -5.5 specifies 5.5 degress South (5 degress and 30 minutes South) Example -121.208178 Minimum Latitude Optional Location of the minimum, or southernmost, data point in this data file, expressed in decimal degrees (southern latitudes are negative). 37.5 specifies 37.5 degress North (37 degrees and 30 minutes North) -5.5 specifies 5.5 degress South (5 degress and 30 minutes South) Example -122.202653 Minimum Longitude Optional Location of the minimum, or westernmost, data point in this data file, expressed in decimal degrees (western longitudes are negative) 150.0 specifies 150 degrees East -122.0 specifies 122 degress West Example 36.892976 Maximum Longitude Optional Location of the maximum, or easternmost, data point in this data file, expressed in decimal degrees (western longitudes are negative) 150.0 specifies 150 degrees East -122.0 specifies 122 degress West Example 37.484637 Bounding Shape Multi-valued A list of geographical coordinates that specifies the external bounday of the polygon that describes the coverage of the data contained within the data file associated with this metadata. Point Number Optional Monotonically increasing identifier of the point in the shape being defined (defined in clockwise order and containing the right side of the closed shape). Latitude Optional Location of this point in north latitude decimal degrees (southern latitudes are negative) 37.5 specifies 37.5 degress North (37 degrees and 30 minutes North) -5.5 specifies 5.5 degress South (5 degress and 30 minutes South) Longitude Optional Location of this point in east longitude decimal degrees (western longitudes are negative) 150.0 specifies 150 degrees East -122.0 specifies 122 degress West Data File Geopolitical Coverage Multi-valued A region specified by the totality of one or more place names Geopolitical region Optional Multi-valued Place name depicting a geopolitical region. We recommend that you use Geonames to specify an identifier for a place. Example https://www.geonames.org/5128581 Data File Elevation Coverage Multi-valued The elevation covered by the data file being described. Vertical Extent Minimum Value Optional A minimum vertical extent in metres of the data file collection. In case of depth, this contains the maximum depth of data file collection (it is a negative number of greater absolute magnitude than the Vertical Extent Maximum Value). Note that the unit is metres. Vertical Extent Maximum Value Optional A maximum vertical extent in metres of data file collection. In case of depth, this contains the minimum depth of data file collection (it is a negative number of lesser absolute magnitude than the Vertical Extent Minimum Value). Note that the unit is metres. Vertical Extent Datum Optional The name of the Datum (reference frame) used for the Vertical Extent values. Vertical Extent Datum IRI Optional The IRI (Internationalized Resource Identifier) of the Datum (reference frame) used for the Vertical Extent values. Auxiliary Metadata Information about the data file or metadata submission that does not fit into the other categories Data File Descriptive Attribute Optional Multi-valued This field supports entry of both the metadata attribute name (in the first field), and the value for that attribute (in the second field). Note this is a repeating field and so can support multiple key-value pairs. Additional Commentary Optional Multi-valued Any additional information about the data file or provided metadata.
docs.title: Specification

docs.text: Multi-valued The name or title of the Data File being described. Mutliple titles may be specified in different languages. At least one Data File Title element is required.
docs.title: Data File Title

docs.text: Required A title or descriptive name by which the Data File being described is known. This is a presentation name (i.e. title case with appropriate spacing) and is typically different from the actual file name of the data file. Example COVID-19 Booster Shot Side Effects Survey Responses
docs.title: Title

docs.text: Optional The language tag that identifies the language in which the Data File Title is provided. Languages are identified using codes that are structured in accordance with RFC 5646 . If no value is specified then the default code of en for English is assumed. A comprehensive list of language codes is provided here. If you cannot find an appropriate language code please contact the Data Hub administrators. The value of this field is a language code. See the language code table for a list of possible language codes. Example en
docs.title: Language

docs.text: Information about the globally unique and persistent identifier used to identify and optionally access (meta)data of the data file being described.
docs.title: Data File Identity

docs.text: Recommended A globally unique string that identifies the Data File being described. It is typically a DOI (Digital Object Identifier) or URL (Uniform Resource Locator, that is, Web address). The identifier is typically generated by data providers or data publishers who wish to have a citable and Web-accessible resource. Example DOIs are doi:10.1000/182 or http://doi.org/10.1000/182 , both of which identify the DOI Handbook, which has a DOI of 10.1000/182 See also: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_object_identifier Example doi:10.1000/182
docs.title: Identifier

docs.text: Optional The identifier type used to identify the resource being described. This need not be provided if the identifier is either a DOI that begins with "doi:" or "http://doi.org/", or it is a URL that begins with either "http://" or "https://" Example DOI
docs.title: Identifier Type

docs.text: Recommended The local name of the resource (for example, in a file-based operating system or web service). Example COVID-19_Booster_Shot_June_2022_Responses.csv
docs.title: File Name

docs.text: Optional A SHA256 digest of the Data File contents. This is a 64 characters long hexadecimal string. As an example, the SHA256 digest of the string, "RADx Data Hub" is ebff8d3da88b292622d3bfc36bdac4c4537ddc56cb07f344c5223d6b6f9cd011 . On macOS the following command may be used to generate the SHA256 digest of a file shasum -a 256 /path/to/file Example ebff8d3da88b292622d3bfc36bdac4c4537ddc56cb07f344c5223d6b6f9cd011
docs.title: SHA256 digest

docs.text: Recommended The kind of content that the data file contains. Data files are either text or non-text (binary) representations of datasets, images etc. This field describes the conceptual type of the thing that is represented by the data file. In most cases the value of this field will "Data Set" but other common types include "Audiovisual", "Data Stream", "Image"" Audiovisual | Collection | Data Catalog | Data Paper | Data Stream | Dataset | Event | Image | Interactive Resource | Model | Other Resource | Physical Object | Service | Software | Sound | Text | Workflow Example Data Set
docs.title: Type Of Content

docs.text: Optional If no suitable value can be specified for the Type Of Content field then this field may contain a brief free-text description of the conceptual type of content
docs.title: Type of Content Description

docs.text: Version of the resource being described.
docs.title: Data File Version

docs.text: Recommended The string identifying the version of the data file or other resource being described. We recommend that provides use semantic versioning of the form, major.minor.patch for example, 2.1.4 . Example 1.0.1
docs.title: Version

docs.text: Language in which the data file being described is provided.
docs.title: Data File Language

docs.text: Optional Primary language used to present the data file (if multiple languages are present). The value of this field is a language code. See the language code table for a list of possible language codes. Example en
docs.title: Primary Language

docs.text: Optional Multi-valued A language in which the data file being described is provided. The value of this field is a language code. See the language code table for a list of possible language codes.
docs.title: Other Language

docs.text: Multi-valued Concepts (keywords, classification, or free text terms) that define the data file or purpose (subjects which can be addressed) using the data file.
docs.title: Data File Subjects

docs.text: Recommended The Medical Subject Headings (MeSH) subject code that identifies a classification subject that is pertinent to the data file. Example http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/MESH/C000719227
docs.title: Subject Identifier

docs.text: Derived Optional This value is derived This field should not be manually specified or edited. The name of the scheme or authority used for the Subject Identifier.
docs.title: Subject Identifier Scheme

docs.text: Derived Optional This value is derived This field should not be manually specified or edited. The unique identifier (IRI) of the scheme or authority used for the Subject Identifier.
docs.title: Subject Identifier Scheme Identifier

docs.text: Optional Free text subject, keyword, classification code, or key phrase describing the data file or purpose for which the data file can be used. While MeSH codes are the preferred form of specifying subjects this free text field may be used for codes or subject keywords that do not have a corresponding MeSH terms. Example COVID-19 vaccine booster shot
docs.title: Keyword

docs.text: Multi-valued Summary of the Data File and its contents.
docs.title: Data File Description

docs.text: Recommended An account of the resource contained in the Data File; may include but is not limited to: an abstract, a table of contents, a graphical representation, or a free-text account of the resource. Example This dataset provides responses from a survey carried out in June 2022 whose purpose was to ascertain side-effects of receiving the COVID-19 booster shot.
docs.title: Description

docs.text: Optional Language in which the Data File description is provided. The default value is en for English. The value of this field is a language code. See the language code table for a list of possible language codes. Example en
docs.title: Description Language

docs.text: Information about the Data Dictionary associated with the Data File
docs.title: Data File Dictionary

docs.text: Optional The file name of the Data Dictionary file that defines the Data File's data elements. Example COVID-19_Booster_Shot_June_2022_Responses--DataDictionary.csv
docs.title: Data Dictionary File Name

docs.text: Multi-valued Information about the person or organization that created the data file.
docs.title: Data File Creator

docs.text: Recommended The type of the creator. This is either a Person or an Organization. Organization | Person Example Person
docs.title: Creator Type

docs.text: Recommended The full name of the creator. For a person this is the combination of the given name and family name, in the appropriate order. Example Josiah Carberry
docs.title: Creator Name

docs.text: Recommended If the creator is a person, the personal name(s) of the creator (e.g., first and optionally middle name in Western languagues, optionally middle and last name in Asian languages). Example Josiah
docs.title: Creator Given Name

docs.text: Recommended If the creator is a person, the surname(s) of the creator (e.g., last name in Western languagues, first name in Asian languages). Example Carberry
docs.title: Creator Family Name

docs.text: Recommended Globally unique string that identifies the creator (an individual or legal entity). This is typically an ORCID. The ORCID iD is an https URI with a 16-digit number that is compatible with the ISO Standard (ISO 27729), also known as the International Standard Name Identifier (ISNI), e.g. https://orcid.org/0000-0001-2345-6789 ORCID provides a persistent digital identifier (an ORCID iD) that you own and control, and that distinguishes you from every other researcher. You can connect your iD with your professional information — affiliations, grants, publications, peer review, and more. You can use your iD to share your information with other systems, ensuring you get recognition for all your contributions, saving you time and hassle, and reducing the risk of errors. For more details on ORCiDs see https://orgid.org Example https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1825-0097
docs.title: Creator Identifier

docs.text: Optional The name of the scheme or authority used for the Creator Identifier. If the Creator Identiifier is an ORCID that starts with https://orcid.org then there is no need to fill out this field. GRID | ISNI | LinkedIn ID | ORCiD | ResearcherID | ROR | Scopus Example ORCID
docs.title: Creator Identifier Scheme

docs.text: Derived Optional The value of this field is derived from the value of the Creator Identifier Scheme field. This field should not be manually specified or edited. The unique identifier (IRI) of the scheme or authority used for the Creator Identifier. If the Creator Identiifier is an ORCID that starts with https://orcid.org then there is no need to fill out this field.
docs.title: Creator Identifier Scheme Identifier

docs.text: Recommended The email address of the creator. Example josiah.carberry@example.com
docs.title: Creator Email

docs.text: Recommended If the creator is a Person who is affiliated with an instition then this field should specify the institution. Example Brown University
docs.title: Creator Affiliation

docs.text: Optional Globally unique string that identifies the organizational affiliation of the creator. Example https://ror.org/05gq02987
docs.title: Creator Affiliation Identifier

docs.text: Optional The name of the scheme or authority used for the Creator Affiliation Identifier. GRID | ISNI | LinkedIn ID | ORCiD | ResearcherID | ROR | Scopus Example ROR
docs.title: Creator Affiliation Identifier Scheme

docs.text: Derived Optional The value of this field is derived from the Creator Affiliation Scheme field This field should not be manually specified or edited. The unique identifier (IRI) of the scheme or authority used for the Subject Identifier.
docs.title: Creator Affiliation Identifier Scheme Identifier

docs.text: Recommended The role of the Person or the Organization in relation to the data file creation. Contact Person | Data Collector | Data Curator | Data Manager | Distributor | Editor | Hosting Institution | Other Role | Producer | Project Leader | Project Manager | Project Member | Registration Agency | Registration Authority | Related Person | Research Group | Researcher | Rights Holder | Sponsor | Supervisor | Work Package Leader
docs.title: Creator Role

docs.text: Multi-valued Information about resource related to the data file or other entity being described. TODO: INSERT MORE EXPLANATION HERE
docs.title: Data File Related Resource

docs.text: Optional A globally unique string that identifies a resource that is related to the data file being described.
docs.title: Related Resource Identifier

docs.text: Optional The identifier type used to identify the related resource. ARK | arXiv | bibcode | DOI | EAN13 | EISSN | Handle | IGSN | IRI | ISBN | ISSN | ISTC | LISSN | LSID | PMID | PURL | UPC | URI | URL | URN | w3id
docs.title: Related Resource Identifier Type

docs.text: Optional The local name of the related resource file (given by the operating system or web service).
docs.title: Related Resource File Name

docs.text: Optional Categorical type of the resource being described. (Corresponds to DataCite's resourceTypeGeneral.) Audiovisual | Collection | Data Catalog | Data Paper | Data Stream | Dataset | Event | Image | Interactive Resource | Model | Other Resource | Physical Object | Service | Software | Sound | Text | Workflow
docs.title: Resource Type Category

docs.text: Optional Description of the relationship of the object being described (A) to the related resource (B).
docs.title: Relation of Data File to Resource

docs.text: Multi-valued An entity that contributed in bringing into existence the data file being described. Contributors can be people or organizations. While data file creators are also contributors, data file creators should be provided in the Data File Creator section instead of here
docs.title: Data File Contributor

docs.text: Optional The type of the contributor of the described data file (person or organization). Organization | Person Example Person
docs.title: Contributor Type

docs.text: Optional The full name of the contributor. Example Josiah Carberry
docs.title: Contributor Name

docs.text: Optional If the contributor is a person, the personal name(s) of the contributor (e.g., first and optionally middle name in Western languagues, optionally middle and last name in Asian languages). Example Josiah
docs.title: Contributor Given Name

docs.text: Optional If the contributor is a person, the surname(s) of the conributor (e.g., last name in Western languagues, first name in Asian languages). Example Carberry
docs.title: Contributor Family Name

docs.text: Optional Globally unique string that identifies the contributor (an individual or legal entity). Example https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1825-0097
docs.title: Contributor Identifier

docs.text: Optional The name of the scheme or authority used for the Contributor Identifier. GRID | ISNI | LinkedIn ID | ORCiD | ResearcherID | ROR | Scopus Example ORCID
docs.title: Contributor Identifier Scheme

docs.text: Derived Optional The value of this field is derived from the value of the Contributor Identifier Scheme Field This field should not be manually specified or edited. The unique identifier (IRI) of the scheme or authority used for the Contributor Identifier.
docs.title: Contributor Identifier Scheme IRI

docs.text: Optional If the contributor is a person, the organizational or institutional affiliation of the contributor. Example Brown University
docs.title: Contributor Affiliation

docs.text: Optional Globally unique string that identifies the organizational affiliation of the contributor. Example https://ror.org/05gq02987
docs.title: Contributor Affiliation Identifier

docs.text: Optional The name of the scheme or authority used for the Contributor Affiliation Identifier. GRID | ISNI | LinkedIn ID | ORCiD | ResearcherID | ROR | Scopus Example ROR
docs.title: Contributor Affiliation Identifier Scheme

docs.text: Derived Optional The value of this field is derived from the value of the Contributor Affiliation Scheme Field This field should not be manually specified or edited. The unique identifier (IRI) of the scheme or authority used for the Contributor Affiliation Identifier Scheme.
docs.title: Contributor Affiliation Identifier Scheme IRI

docs.text: Optional An email address of the contributor. Example josiah.carberry@example.com
docs.title: Contributor Email

Contact Person | Data Collector | Data Curator | Data Manager | Distributor | Editor | Hosting Institution | Other Role | Producer | Project Leader | Project Manager | Project Member | Registration Agency | Registration Authority | Related Person | Research Group | Researcher | Rights Holder | Sponsor | Supervisor | Work Package Leader Example Data Collector

docs.title: License Identifier

docs.text: Optional Text string describing any rights information for the data file being described. Example Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International (CC BY-SA 4.0)
docs.title: License Text

docs.text: Multi-valued Relevant date related to the data file being described. These dates pertain to some data file related event, for example "creation date", "submission date" etc. Dates are specified as a pair containing the actual date (in ISO-8601 format) and the event that the date relates to. See individual fields for specific examples. The dates of some types of events can be captured by the RADx Data Hub, for example the "Submitted" date/time.
docs.title: Data File Date

docs.text: Optional Type of data file event that the date is associated with. Accepted | Available | Collected | Copyrighted | Created | Issued | Published | Submitted | Updated | Valid | Withdrawn Example Submitted
docs.title: Event Type

docs.text: Optional The date/time that is specific to the associated event. Note that dates must be specified in ISO-8601 format. This format specifies date/times in a locale neutral way with temporal components ordered largest to smallest, for example year, month, day. Note that times are in 24 hour clock (military time) format, thus 13:43 is 1:43pm. When times are specified a timezone must also be specified. The date time 2022-11-23T01:23:45.678+09:00 specifies November 23, 2022 at just past 1:23am Pacific Time. The date 2022-09-23 specifies September 23, 2022 (without a time stamp). Example 2022-11-23T01:23:45.678+09:00
docs.title: Date

The official start date for the study for which this data file was created. This date must be in the ISO-8601 format of yyyy-mm-dd. For example, 2022-10-05 specified October 5, 2022. Example 2021-10-05

docs.text: Multi-valued Details about the distribution for this individual public presentation of the data file (if part of the Distribution metadata), or for all the public presentations of the data file being described (if part of the data file metadata).
docs.title: Data File Distribution

docs.text: Optional The organization or resource that provides services to make publicly available this distribution of the data file.
docs.title: Distribution Publisher

docs.text: Optional Globally unique string that identifies the Distribution Publisher.
docs.title: Distribution Publisher Identifier

docs.text: Optional Name of the scheme or authority for the Distribution Publisher Identifier. GRID | ISNI | LinkedIn ID | ORCiD | ResearcherID | ROR | Scopus
docs.title: Distribution Publisher Identifier Scheme

docs.text: Derived Optional The value of this field is derived from the Distribution Publisher Identifier Scheme field. This field should not be manually specified or edited. The unique identifier (IRI) of the scheme or authority used for the Distribution Publisher Identifier.
docs.title: Distribution Publisher Identifier Scheme IRI

docs.text: Optional A globally unique string that identifies the data file distribution.
docs.title: Distribution Identifier

docs.text: Optional The identifier type used to identify the data file distribution. ARK | arXiv | bibcode | DOI | EAN13 | EISSN | Handle | IGSN | IRI | ISBN | ISSN | ISTC | LISSN | LSID | PMID | PURL | UPC | URI | URL | URN | w3id
docs.title: Distribution Identifier Type

docs.text: Optional An established standard to which the data file distribution conforms.
docs.title: Distribution Format

docs.title: Distribution Media Type

docs.text: Optional Total size of data file distribution (in bytes).
docs.title: Distribution Size

docs.text: Optional The protocol used to access the data file distribution.
docs.title: Distribution Access Protocol

docs.text: Optional The access protocol configuration for querying the data file distribution.
docs.title: Distribution Access Configuration

docs.text: Optional Technical statement(s) for querying the data file distribution.
docs.title: Distribution Query Statement

docs.text: Publication date of this distribution the data file.
docs.title: Data File Publication Date

docs.text: Optional Date on which this distribution of the data file was published
docs.title: Data File Publication Date

docs.text: Derived Optional The value of this field is a fixed type and is automatically inserted. This field should not be manually specified or edited. Type of the date ('Published') with respect to the data file.
docs.title: Publication Date Type

docs.text: Characteristics of the data within the data file, particularly of the cohorts in the data file.
docs.title: Data Characteristics Summary

docs.text: Optional Formatted HTML code for a table of statistical values
docs.title: Data Characteristics Table in HTML

docs.text: Optional Enter comma-separated values containing summary statistics characterizing this data file
docs.title: Data Characteristics Table in CSV

docs.text: Optional Enter tab-separated values containing summary statistics characterizing this data file
docs.title: Data Characteristics Table in TSV

docs.text: Optional Multi-valued Enter the name of the characteristic being described in the first (key) field, and the value for that characteristic in the second (value) field.. Note this is a repeating field and so can support multiple key-value pairs.
docs.title: Data Characteristics Table in Key-Value Pairs

docs.text: Multi-valued Physical or conceptual entity (agent) that creates the data streams that make up the described data file. The data source may or may not be associated with a fixed location; for example, a series of discrete sensors deployed over time to a single location may be considered a single data source in some systems.
docs.title: Data Source

docs.text: Optional Human readable name of data source from which the variable(s) come(s). Physical or conceptual entity that creates the data streams that make up the described data file. The data source may or may not be associated with a fixed location; for example, a series of discrete sensors deployed over time to a single location may be considered a single data source in some systems.
docs.title: Data Source Name

docs.text: Optional Globally unique string that identifies the data source (e.g., PID of an instrument).
docs.title: Data Source Identifier

docs.text: Optional The name of the scheme or authority used for the Data Source Identifier. ARK | arXiv | bibcode | DOI | EAN13 | EISSN | Handle | IGSN | IRI | ISBN | ISSN | ISTC | LISSN | LSID | PMID | PURL | UPC | URI | URL | URN | w3id
docs.title: Data Source Identifier Scheme

docs.text: Derived Optional The value of this field is derived from the Data Source Identifier Scheme field. This field should not be manually specified or edited. The unique identifier (IRI) of the scheme or authority used for the Data Source Identifier.
docs.title: Data Source Identifier Scheme IRI

docs.text: Multi-valued A collection of one or more variable records that make up this data set. Each data stream originates from a single data source (e.g., sensor, process, or person). A data stream can grow over time.
docs.title: Data Stream

docs.text: Optional Human readable name of collection of records coming from a data source. A data stream is a collection of one or more variable records originating from a single data source (e.g., sensor, process, or person). A data stream can grow over time.
docs.title: Data Stream Name

docs.text: Optional Globally unique string that identifies the collection of records coming from a data source.
docs.title: Data Stream Identifier

docs.text: Optional The name of the scheme or authority used for the Data Stream Identifier. ARK | arXiv | bibcode | DOI | EAN13 | EISSN | Handle | IGSN | IRI | ISBN | ISSN | ISTC | LISSN | LSID | PMID | PURL | UPC | URI | URL | URN | w3id
docs.title: Data Stream Identifier Scheme

docs.text: Derived Optional The value of this field is derived from the Data Stream Identifier Scheme field. This field should not be manually specified or edited. The unique identifier (IRI) of the scheme or authority used for the Data Stream Identifier.
docs.title: Data Stream Identifier Scheme IRI

docs.text: Optional Multi-valued The local name of a variable contained in the data stream.
docs.title: Data Stream Variable Name

docs.text: Optional Globally unique string that identifies the data source (e.g., PID of an instrument) that generated this Data Stream.
docs.title: Data Stream Data Source Identifier

docs.text: Multi-valued Process (activity) used to make the data file or product.
docs.title: Data File Creation Process

docs.text: Optional Full name of the process that operates to make the data file or product.
docs.title: Process Name

docs.text: Optional Unique identifier (IRI) for the process used to make the data file or product (preferably a resolvable and persistent identifier)
docs.title: Process IRI

docs.text: Optional Version of the process used to make this data file, typically a string (e.g., '3.0.3')
docs.title: Process Version

docs.text: Optional Identification of the particular run of the process used to make this data file (a deterministic string; in software, typically either a timestamp combined with the machine on which the software was executed; or a unique identifier generated by the controlling software for each run of the process).
docs.title: Process Execution Identifier

docs.text: Multi-valued A temporal description that specifies the temporal coverage of the data contained within the data file associated with this metadata.
docs.title: Data File Temporal Coverage

docs.text: Optional The start date (and optionally time) of the data. Example 2022-06-01
docs.title: Temporal Extent Minimum Value

docs.text: Optional The end date (and optionally time) of the data. Example 2022-06-29
docs.title: Temporal Extent Maximum Value

docs.text: Optional Interval between two consecutive data records.
docs.title: Temporal Resolution

docs.text: Derived Optional The value of this field is computed from the difference between the Temporal Extent Minimum Value and Temporal Extent Maximum Value fields. This field should not be manually specified or edited. The total duration of data temporal coverage.
docs.title: Duration

docs.text: Multi-valued A geospatial description that specifies the geographical coverage of the data contained within the data file associated with this metadata.
docs.title: Data File Spatial Coverage

docs.text: Multi-valued A geographical bounding box that specifies the geographical coverage of the data contained within the data file associated with this metadata.
docs.title: Bounding Box

docs.text: Optional Location of the maximum, or northernmost, data point in this data file, expressed in decimal degrees (southern latitudes are negative). 37.5 specifies 37.5 degress North (37 degrees and 30 minutes North) -5.5 specifies 5.5 degress South (5 degress and 30 minutes South) Example -121.208178
docs.title: Maximum Latitude

docs.text: Optional Location of the minimum, or southernmost, data point in this data file, expressed in decimal degrees (southern latitudes are negative). 37.5 specifies 37.5 degress North (37 degrees and 30 minutes North) -5.5 specifies 5.5 degress South (5 degress and 30 minutes South) Example -122.202653
docs.title: Minimum Latitude

docs.text: Optional Location of the minimum, or westernmost, data point in this data file, expressed in decimal degrees (western longitudes are negative) 150.0 specifies 150 degrees East -122.0 specifies 122 degress West Example 36.892976
docs.title: Minimum Longitude

docs.text: Optional Location of the maximum, or easternmost, data point in this data file, expressed in decimal degrees (western longitudes are negative) 150.0 specifies 150 degrees East -122.0 specifies 122 degress West Example 37.484637
docs.title: Maximum Longitude

docs.text: Multi-valued A list of geographical coordinates that specifies the external bounday of the polygon that describes the coverage of the data contained within the data file associated with this metadata.
docs.title: Bounding Shape

docs.text: Optional Monotonically increasing identifier of the point in the shape being defined (defined in clockwise order and containing the right side of the closed shape).
docs.title: Point Number

docs.text: Optional Location of this point in north latitude decimal degrees (southern latitudes are negative) 37.5 specifies 37.5 degress North (37 degrees and 30 minutes North) -5.5 specifies 5.5 degress South (5 degress and 30 minutes South)
docs.title: Latitude

docs.text: Optional Location of this point in east longitude decimal degrees (western longitudes are negative) 150.0 specifies 150 degrees East -122.0 specifies 122 degress West
docs.title: Longitude

docs.text: Multi-valued A region specified by the totality of one or more place names
docs.title: Data File Geopolitical Coverage

docs.text: Optional Multi-valued Place name depicting a geopolitical region. We recommend that you use Geonames to specify an identifier for a place. Example https://www.geonames.org/5128581
docs.title: Geopolitical region

docs.text: Multi-valued The elevation covered by the data file being described.
docs.title: Data File Elevation Coverage

docs.text: Optional A minimum vertical extent in metres of the data file collection. In case of depth, this contains the maximum depth of data file collection (it is a negative number of greater absolute magnitude than the Vertical Extent Maximum Value). Note that the unit is metres.
docs.title: Vertical Extent Minimum Value

docs.text: Optional A maximum vertical extent in metres of data file collection. In case of depth, this contains the minimum depth of data file collection (it is a negative number of lesser absolute magnitude than the Vertical Extent Minimum Value). Note that the unit is metres.
docs.title: Vertical Extent Maximum Value

docs.text: Optional The name of the Datum (reference frame) used for the Vertical Extent values.
docs.title: Vertical Extent Datum

docs.text: Optional The IRI (Internationalized Resource Identifier) of the Datum (reference frame) used for the Vertical Extent values.
docs.title: Vertical Extent Datum IRI

docs.text: Information about the data file or metadata submission that does not fit into the other categories
docs.title: Auxiliary Metadata

docs.text: Optional Multi-valued This field supports entry of both the metadata attribute name (in the first field), and the value for that attribute (in the second field). Note this is a repeating field and so can support multiple key-value pairs.
docs.title: Data File Descriptive Attribute

docs.text: Optional Multi-valued Any additional information about the data file or provided metadata.
docs.title: Additional Commentary
